title: Riverfront property fit for a king
text:
THE riverfront home of Brisbane Broncos chairman Karl Morris has sold off-market in one of the biggest residential sales in the city’s history.

The Courier-Mail understands that the sprawling estate at 1 King Arthur Terrace in Tennyson, which sits on a whopping 4224sqm, has sold for more than $16 million.

That would make it one of the top sales ever achieved in Brisbane, with the current record-holder being 1 Leopard St at Kangaroo Point, which sold for $18,488,888 in 2016.

The clifftop trophy home is currently listed for sale.

RELATED: Inside Brisbane’s $18m trophy home at Kangaroo Point

Mining magnate Gina Rinehart purchased 46 Aaron Avenue at Hawthorne for $14 million in 2014, the third highest sale, before later acquiring an adjoining property for an additional $4 million.

Morris, who would not be drawn on the sale price, confirmed the Tennyson property had sold off-market to a local family.

Property records show Morris and his wife Louise paid $6.8 million for the prime spot, which sits where Oxley Creek meets the Brisbane River, back in 2008.

It was bought off former richlister and entrepreneur Ross Palmer, who had previously purchased the property off former mining executive Ian Howard-Smith and his wife Margaret in 1997.

Even back then, it was a multi-million dollar site.

After taking ownership, the Morris’ demolished the Tuscan-style house on the block, and engaged renowned architect Bayden Goddard of BGD Architects to create their dream home.

Speaking exclusively to the Courier Mail, Morris said they were downsizing, with three of their five children now out of home and another expected to fly the nest soon.

He said that he would also be required to spend more time in Sydney, after completing the buy-out of shareholders at private wealth management group, Ord Minnett, of which Morris is the executive chairman.

But the businessman said he would remain as the chairman of the Brisbane Broncos, and would always have ties to the river city.

“We built it (the house at Tennyson) in 2010,” he said. “It took about 18 months (to complete the new build) … we were living locally while that was occurring.”

Morris said his wife was the main design influence, with the riverfront stunner being the second house they had “done” with Goddard, who has had a creative hand in the design of some of Queensland’s most showstopping homes.

“My favourite thing about the property is how quiet it is … there is one neighbour and the golf course (Indooroopilly Golf Club) is across the river,” he said.

The residence has seven bedrooms, five bathrooms, garaging for six vehicles, a pool and a championship-size tennis court.

It also boasts possibly Brisbane’s biggest private pontoon at 40m, 98m of river frontage and unobstructed northern views up the Brisbane River to the Walter Taylor Bridge.

The property has just one neighbour, and is otherwise flanked by bushland, the Brisbane River and Oxley Creek, with parkland and golf course views.

Morris said he could remember being on the river and seeing the property in his younger years, but “never in a million years did I think I would end up there”.

The family is now expected to move out of the property before the end of the year, with Morris confirming they would be looking to buy a smaller house in Brisbane.

“We have a Great Dane,” he said, ruling out a luxury apartment.
description: The riverfront home of Brisbane Broncos chairman Karl Morris has sold off-market in one of the biggest residential sales in the city’s history.
